title: Makazole Mapimpi encapsulates the transformation South African rugby is undergoing
text:
If you thought South American footballer commentators were overexcitable then you ought to listen to the Xhosa commentary of Makazole Mapimpi’s two tries for South Africa against Japan in the World Cup quarter-final. The sound is slightly terrifying, like hearing two men narrating a plane’s descent into a tailspin, but still utterly joyful.

Xhosa is one of four languages used within the Springbok camp – the others being English, Afrikaans and Sotho – and is primarily spoken within the Eastern Cape where Mapimpi hails from. He had a hard background. His family home was little more than a shack. Every day he would walk 10km to school. He did not earn a scholarship to one of the big rugby schools...
